results.headline: The Tread Life on This Tire Is Something Else

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rubber

results.summary_short: In “Rubber,” a horror film by Quentin Dupieux, a rogue tire has an unstable mind of its own.

results.headline: Snipping Off Appendages and Other Comic Ploys

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cat Run

results.summary_short: “Cat Run,” a puerile, violent comedy directed by John Stockwell, is an incoherent buddy movie that features severed body parts and naked prostitutes.

results.headline: Don’t Know Who You Are, but Don’t Know Who I Am

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Source Code

results.summary_short: In Duncan Jones’s science-fiction film, a man who knows himself to be a helicopter pilot wakes up on a train traveling to Chicago, only to find he is in someone else’s body.

results.headline: Something’s Going On in That House

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Insidious

results.summary_short: In “Insidious,” the team behind “Saw” comes up with a ghost story with virtually no gore or instruments of torture.

results.headline: The Ways of the Predator

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trust

results.summary_short: “Trust,” directed by David Schwimmer, examines a family blindsided by a stranger stalking their daughter online.

results.headline: A Do-Gooder Vision Clouded by Blind Spots

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In a Better World

results.summary_short: “In a Better World” is set in a Danish town and a refugee camp in Africa, and is an elegant, somber scourge for the guilty conscience of the affluent, liberal West.

results.headline: Bunny Doesn’t Want to Work, Just Wants to Bang the Drum All Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hop

results.summary_short: “Hop,” a Christianity-free Easter tale of rabbits and humans, stars Hugh Laurie and Russell Brand.

results.headline: A Road-Trip Diet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fat, Sick & Nearly Dead

results.summary_short: In the documentary “Fat, Slick & Nearly Dead” an Australian comes to America to lose weight and show people how to do it themselves.

results.headline: A Punishing Drive

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wrecked

results.summary_short: In “Wrecked,” Adrien Brody plays the sole survivor of a car crash who regains consciousness to find his leg trapped and his memory hazy.

results.headline: Eternal Complexities of the Very Simple Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Times

results.summary_short: “Le Quattro Volte,” an idiosyncratic and amazing new film by Michelangelo Frammartino, is so full of surprises that even to describe it is to risk giving something away.

results.headline: Conor Horgan’s ‘One Hundred Mornings’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Hundred Mornings

results.summary_short: Conor Horgan’s “One Hundred Mornings” uses an apocalyptic event as a springboard into the human psyche.

results.headline: The Sequel to ‘Diary of a Wimpy Kid’
results.display_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules

results.summary_short: “Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules” is the second film to come from Jeff Kinney’s illustrated children’s books.

results.headline: Well, Here They Are, Wherever This May Be

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sucker Punch

results.summary_short: “Sucker Punch,” directed by Zack Snyder, follows its characters through a mental hospital, a bordello and various battlefields.

results.headline: Stories of War Through a Gypsy Lens

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Korkoro

results.summary_short: “Korkoro” has an unexpectedly leisurely quality as it shows the texture of Gypsy life.

results.headline: Things Fall Apart When a Family Gets Together

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Peep World

results.summary_short: In “Peep World” a member of a dysfunctional family writes a tell-all novel and consequences unfold.

results.headline: Moods and Messages From the Earth
results.display_title: I Travel Because I Have To, I Come Back Because I Love You

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Travel Because I Have To, I Come Back Because I Love You

results.summary_short: As singular as its title, “I Travel Because I Have To, I Come Back Because I Love You” embraces road movie, personal journal and trancelike study of arcing grief.

results.headline: Hopes and Struggles in a Difficult Land

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miral

results.summary_short: Julian Schnabel brings “Miral,” based on Rula Jebreal’s novel, to the screen.

results.headline: Seeking a Missing Father and Mending the Earth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mia and the Migoo

results.summary_short: In “Mia and the Migoo” a girl joins with fantastical forest creatures to seek her father, and also helps save the forest.

results.headline: John Gray’s ‘White Irish Drinkers’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of White Irish Drinkers

results.summary_short: Set in the Bay Ridge area of Brooklyn in 1975, “White Irish Drinkers” is a fill-in-the-blanks kitchen-sink drama.

results.headline: A Woman With a Son, but Not a Country

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Illégal

results.summary_short: “Illegal,” by Olivier Masset-Depasse, follows the desperate struggles of an immigrant trying to stay in her adopted land.
